title: Moneycorp Eyes Expansion With Brazilian Deal
text:

Tue, Aug 11, 2015, 22:10 BST - UK Markets closed Moneycorp Eyes Expansion With Brazilian Deal By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 9 minutes ago View Photo 

Moneycorp, the UK-based foreign currency provider, will underline the consolidation sweeping parts of the financial services sector on Wednesday when it acquires a stake in one of Brazil's fastest-growing foreign exchange businesses. 
Sources have told Sky News that Moneycorp, which is backed by the private equity group Bridgepoint, will announce that it is buying a minority shareholding in Novo Mundo Corretora de Cambio, subject to local regulatory approval. 
The deal is expected to be modest in size but underlines the land-grab taking place in the retail foreign exchange sector as established players seek more rapid growth in emerging markets. 
An insider said that it would enable Moneycorp to serve customers’ growing demand for international payments flows, with Brazil offering a platform to expand further into South America. 
Moneycorp's move to buy the Novo Mundo stake, its first overseas deal since Bridgepoint's takeover last year, will also highlight its ambitions after being released from the comparatively shackled ownership of a fund housed within Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) (RBS). 
The company, which is run by Mark Horgan, a former executive at Travelex and MasterCard, is likely to have the right to increase its stake in Novo Mundo in future. 
Founded in 1999 at a shop on Oxford Street in London's West End, Moneycorp handles transactions worth more than £8bn annually and employs more than 500 people. 
The spin-off of the RBS-managed Special Opportunities Fund (NYSE: SPE - news ) reflected a growing trend among global banks to downsize their investment businesses because of more punitive capital treatment by international regulators. 
Moneycorp's sale will follow a frenetic period of deals involving major foreign currency providers. 
On Tuesday, Currencies Direct, a specialist provider of foreign exchange and international payment solutions to private and corporate clients, was sold to two private equity firms in a deal worth more than £200m. 
Travelex, meanwhile, was sold to an Abu Dhabi-based consortium last year, while HiFX, a much smaller competitor, was bought by Euronet, a US-based company. 
Moneycorp declined to comment.
